questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic male presents with fever, headache and right eyelid pain. Examination reveals vesicles in upper eye lid, forehead and nose on the right side of face consistent with herpes zoster. Which of the following nerves is likely involved:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ophthalmic nerve

The ophthalmic nerve (V1), a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), is the division most commonly affected in herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It provides sensory innervation to the cornea, upper eyelid, forehead, and dorsum of the nose. When herpes zoster reactivates in the trigeminal ganglion, involvement of the ophthalmic division results in vesicular eruptions along its cutaneous distribution — including the upper eyelid, forehead, and side of the nose. The characteristic skin lesions described in this patient (vesicles over the upper eyelid, forehead, and nose) are classic for herpes zoster involving the ophthalmic nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic Diaphragm?
1.Pubococcygeous
2.Iliococcygeous
3.Puborectalis
4. Deep Transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1, 2, 3

The pelvic diaphragm is primarily formed by the levator ani group of muscles (pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis) along with the coccygeus (ischiococcygeus). These muscles together form a supportive sling across the pelvic outlet, providing support to the pelvic organs and maintaining continence. Specifically:

Pubococcygeus forms the bulk of the levator ani and supports pelvic viscera.

Iliococcygeus contributes to the posterolateral part of the diaphragm.

Puborectalis forms a sling around the anorectal junction, playing a crucial role in fecal continence.

questions.text: Tongue muscle which is NOT developed from occipital myotome:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Palatoglossus

The palatoglossus muscle is unique among the tongue muscles because it is not derived from the occipital myotomes. Instead, it originates from the fourth pharyngeal arch mesoderm. Consequently, its nerve supply is different from the other tongue muscles—it is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus of nerves via the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X). This sets it apart from the other intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, which are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII) and develop from occipital myotomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of White fibrous cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epiphyseal Cartilage

Epiphyseal cartilage, also known as the epiphyseal plate or growth plate, is not an example of white fibrous cartilage. Instead, it is a type of hyaline cartilage. Hyaline cartilage is characterized by its smooth, glassy appearance and is mainly responsible for longitudinal growth of long bones during childhood and adolescence. The presence of chondrocytes in lacunae, a homogeneous matrix, and absence of prominent fibers distinguish hyaline cartilage from fibrocartilage. Since the epiphyseal cartilage plays a crucial role in endochondral ossification and bone lengthening, it belongs to hyaline cartilage, not fibrous cartilage.

questions.text: Which structures of Brachial Plexus do not give any branches?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Division

The divisions of the brachial plexus (each trunk splitting into an anterior and a posterior division) are purely transitional structures. Their role is only to reorganize fibers before they regroup into cords. Importantly, no branches arise from the divisions. This makes divisions unique within the brachial plexus as every other part (roots, trunks, cords) gives off named branches.

questions.text: A patient developed Hoarseness of Voice due to left recurrent Laryngeal Nerve weakness. Echocardiography revealed enlargement of the base of the heart compressing the nerve. Which chamber of the heart is enlarged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left Atrium

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops around the arch of the aorta (near the ligamentum arteriosum) before ascending in the tracheoesophageal groove to reach the larynx. Because of this anatomical course, it is especially vulnerable to compression by structures in the mediastinum. The left atrium lies posterior to the esophagus and close to the pathway of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. Enlargement of the left atrium—commonly due to conditions like mitral stenosis or left ventricular failure—can compress the nerve, leading to hoarseness of voice, a condition known as Ortner’s syndrome (cardiovocal syndrome)

questions.text:
The  following  diagram  depicts   the  various  parts  from  which  the diaphragm  develops . 
Defects  in   which  part  most  commonly   leads  to  congenital  diaphragmatic   hernia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

D

The diagram represents the embryological components that contribute to the formation of the diaphragm: septum transversum, pleuroperitoneal membranes, dorsal mesentery of esophagus, and body wall mesoderm. The most common site for congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is due to failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal membranes (D). This results in a Bochdalek hernia, typically on the left side, where abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity. This prevents normal lung development, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress in the newborn. Defects in the pleuroperitoneal membranes are the most frequent cause of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: Following statement about  through the marked structure is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ophthalmic division carries information from the tip of nose

The marked structure in the image is the trigeminal ganglion (Gasserian ganglion), from which the three divisions of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) arise: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3). The ophthalmic division (V1) is purely sensory and supplies the cornea, forehead, scalp, and the tip of the nose (via the external nasal branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve). This is clinically important because in Herpes Zoster ophthalmicus, involvement of the tip of the nose indicates likely ocular involvement (Hutchinson’s sign)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cockayne Syndrome

Cockayne Syndrome is not associated with defective homologous recombination repair. Instead, it is a disorder of defective transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair (TC-NER). Patients present with growth failure, neurodegeneration, photosensitivity, and premature aging. Since the DNA repair defect in Cockayne syndrome specifically involves the removal of UV-induced DNA damage through nucleotide excision repair (and not homologous recombination

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of Muscle weakness to the OPD. The patient was diagnosed with Barth Syndrome, where the patient has mitochondrial Dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cardiolipin

Barth Syndrome is a rare X-linked mitochondrial disorder caused by mutations in the TAZ gene, which encodes the enzyme tafazzin. This enzyme is required for the remodeling of cardiolipin, a phospholipid found exclusively in the inner mitochondrial membrane. Cardiolipin plays a critical role in maintaining the integrity and function of the electron transport chain (ETC) and ATP production. A defect in cardiolipin results in impaired oxidative phosphorylation, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, neutropenia, and growth delay.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with easy Fatiguability. The mother also complaints that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination reveals no Glycogen. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Glycogen Synthase

Glycogen synthase is the key enzyme responsible for the elongation of glycogen chains during glycogen synthesis. A deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to store glycogen in the liver, resulting in absent or markedly reduced glycogen stores. Clinically, this manifests as easy fatigability due to the lack of stored glucose for release during fasting, and increased hunger between meals because blood glucose drops quickly after food is digested. Since liver glycogen is absent on examination, glycogen synthase deficiency is the most consistent explanation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with Vomiting, irritability and Lethargy. He was then diagnosed with a urea cycle disorder that is inherited as an X-linked Recessive Disorder. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type II Hyperammonemia

Type II Hyperammonemia results from a deficiency of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC), a key enzyme of the urea cycle located in the mitochondria. This disorder is important because it is the only urea cycle disorder inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, while all others are autosomal recessive. Affected children usually present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, poor feeding, and hyperammonemia due to impaired nitrogen disposal. The clue in the question—X-linked inheritance—points directly to Type II Hyperammonemia,

questions.text:
Which of the MPS will not present as Mental Retardation?

I) Scheie Disease

II) Natowicz Syndrome

III) Morquio Disease

IV) Maroteaux Lamy Disease

V) Sly Syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

I, III, IV

The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are lysosomal storage disorders caused by deficiencies of enzymes that degrade glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). A key clinical distinction among them is whether or not they involve mental retardation (intellectual disability).

I) Scheie Disease (MPS I-S): This is a milder form of Hurler syndrome. Patients usually have normal intelligence. The main features are corneal clouding, stiff joints, and valvular heart disease, but the CNS is spared.

III) Morquio Disease (MPS IV): Patients with Morquio syndrome typically have skeletal dysplasia (short stature, abnormal spine, chest deformities) and corneal clouding, but intelligence is normal.

IV) Maroteaux-Lamy Disease (MPS VI): This resembles Hurler clinically (with coarse facies, corneal clouding, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities), but unlike Hurler, there is no mental retardation.

questions.text: What is defect in Abetalipoproteinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Defect in MTP
 
Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP). MTP is essential for the assembly and secretion of apolipoprotein B–containing lipoproteins, such as chylomicrons, VLDL, and LDL. In the absence of functional MTP, the liver and intestines cannot form or secrete these lipoproteins, leading to extremely low levels of plasma triglycerides and cholesterol. Clinically, patients present with fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, failure to thrive, acanthocytosis, retinitis pigmentosa, and neurological manifestations due to fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (especially vitamin E)

questions.text: Which of the following disorders have caramel urine odor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Maple Syrup Urine Disease

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex, which is required for the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). The inability to metabolize these amino acids results in their accumulation and the buildup of corresponding ketoacids. A hallmark of the disease is the distinctive caramel or maple syrup-like odor of the urine, sweat, and earwax, due to the presence of sotolone (a metabolic byproduct). Clinically, infants present with poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, developmental delay, and if untreated, severe neurological impairment

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to detect DNA-protein interaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DNA foot printing
Explanation: The parts of DNA that are protein-bound are resistant to digestion by nuclease enzymes. Since the nucleases are unable to cleave the protein-bound regions of DNA, when the cleaved DNA fragments are run on polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, there are missing bands indicating, protected sides of protein-bound DNA. These missing areas represent the footprint of the protected DNA-protein complexes. Hence DNA foot printing technique helps to identify the specific protein binding site of protein of DNA sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones does not use JAK-STAT pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Secretin

Secretin does not use the JAK-STAT signaling pathway. Instead, it belongs to the family of peptide hormones that act through G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs). When secretin binds to its receptor on the target cell membrane, it activates adenylate cyclase via Gs protein, leading to increased intracellular cAMP. This second messenger system mediates its physiological effects, such as stimulating bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas.

questions.text: Assuming that vessels A to D are the same length, which one has the greatest flow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The flow in a vessel is directly proportional to the pressure gradient across the vessel and to the fourth power of the radius of the vessel. In contrast, blood flow is inversely proportional to the viscosity of the blood. Because blood flow is proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius, the vessel with the largest radius (vessel D) would have the greatest flow.

questions.text: Which is the most potent algogenic substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bradykinin

Bradykinin is the most potent algogenic substance (pain-producing agent). It is released during tissue injury, inflammation, or ischemia and directly activates nociceptors (pain-sensitive nerve endings). Bradykinin binds to B2 receptors on sensory nerve endings, leading to depolarization and transmission of pain signals. It also increases vascular permeability and causes vasodilation, further amplifying inflammatory pain. Among all algogenic substances, bradykinin is considered the strongest because it produces intense, prolonged pain and also sensitizes nociceptors to other pain mediators such as prostaglandins.

questions.text: A phlebotomist has been asked to take samples from a patient for multiple tests. Which of the following order of Blood collection for testing will not contaminate the sample based on the additives present in the collecting tubes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Light Blue→Red-→Lavender-→ Grey

The order of blood draw is crucial to prevent cross-contamination of additives between tubes. According to the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines, the recommended sequence is:

Light Blue (sodium citrate) – used for coagulation studies (PT, aPTT). Drawing it first avoids contamination with anticoagulants like EDTA or heparin that would alter coagulation results.

Red (no additive / clot activator) – used for serology, chemistry, and immunology tests. It follows because contamination from anticoagulants would interfere with these assays.

Lavender (EDTA) – used for hematology (CBC, blood smears). Drawing after citrate and plain tubes prevents EDTA contamination, which can chelate calcium and distort coagulation or chemistry results if collected earlier.

Grey (fluoride/oxalate) – used for glucose testing. It is drawn last because fluoride strongly inhibits glycolysis, and oxalate can interfere with many other assays if contamination occurs.

questions.text: What does this image shows?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Emperipolesis

The image shows a large cell (likely a histiocyte) containing an intact, viable hematopoietic cell (such as a lymphocyte or neutrophil) within its cytoplasm. This phenomenon is called emperipolesis, which refers to the active penetration and presence of one intact cell within another without being destroyed. It is classically seen in Rosai–Dorfman disease (sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy) but may also be seen in some leukemias and other reactive conditions. The engulfed cells remain alive and unharmed, which distinguishes emperipolesis from phagocytosis.

questions.text: What is the most reliable marker for cellular autophagy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

LC-3

The most reliable marker for cellular autophagy is LC3 (microtubule-associated protein light chain 3). During autophagy, LC3-I (the cytosolic form) is lipidated to LC3-II, which integrates into autophagosome membranes. detection of LC3-II is considered the gold standard for monitoring autophagosome formation and autophagic activity. It directly reflects the number of autophagosomes and is widely used in both research and diagnostic studies to assess autophagy.

questions.text: A patient with Chronic Neutrophilic Leukemia is found to have t (9;22). What will be the size of ABL-BCR fusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

230 KDa

In Chronic Neutrophilic Leukemia (CNL) with t(9;22)(q34;q11) translocation, the fusion gene created is ABL-BCR, unlike Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) where the reciprocal BCR-ABL fusion predominates. The ABL-BCR fusion protein generated in CNL has a molecular weight of 230 kDa. This is characteristic and helps in differentiating it from other hematological malignancies involving the Philadelphia chromosome. The presence of the 230 kDa ABL-BCR fusion protein is therefore diagnostic and specific for CNL associated with this chromosomal translocation.

questions.text: Which of the following are not well stained with Romanowsky stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Heinz Bodies

Heinz bodies are intracellular inclusions composed of denatured hemoglobin, usually formed due to oxidative damage. They are not well stained with Romanowsky stains (such as Wright, Giemsa, or Leishman). Instead, they are best visualized using supravital stains like crystal violet or brilliant cresyl blue. This is because Romanowsky stains fail to highlight precipitated hemoglobin aggregates effectively, making Heinz bodies difficult to detect in routine peripheral smear examination unless special supravital staining is used.

questions.text: Which of the following combination is incorrect?
questions.solution:

Friedrichs Ataxia: CAA

The given combination is incorrect because Friedreich’s Ataxia is caused by a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the frataxin (FXN) gene on chromosome 9, not CAA. This repeat expansion leads to mitochondrial dysfunction due to impaired iron metabolism, resulting in progressive neurodegeneration, ataxia, dysarthria, and cardiomyopathy. the combination of Friedreich’s Ataxia: CAA is wrong — the correct repeat is GAA.

questions.text: What is the reason of decreased level of testosterone in Hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Due to deposition of Iron in Hypothalamic-Pituitary Axis

In hemochromatosis, there is excessive deposition of iron in multiple organs due to abnormal iron metabolism. One of the endocrine manifestations is hypogonadism. This primarily occurs because iron accumulates in the hypothalamus and pituitary gland, leading to dysfunction of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. Specifically, pituitary gonadotroph cells are damaged, reducing secretion of LH and FSH, which in turn decreases stimulation of the testes. This results in secondary hypogonadism (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), and decreased testosterone levels.

questions.text:
Assertion: topical hydroquinone is effective in melasma

Reason: Hydroquinone is a tyrosinase inhibitor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Both assertion and reason are true and reason is correct explanation of assertion

Topical hydroquinone is widely used in the treatment of melasma, a hyperpigmentation disorder, because it decreases melanin production. It works as a tyrosinase inhibitor, blocking the conversion of DOPA to melanin in melanocytes. Since tyrosinase is the rate-limiting enzyme in melanin synthesis, its inhibition directly reduces pigment production. The assertion that hydroquinone is effective in melasma is true, and the reason that it acts by inhibiting tyrosinase is also true.

questions.text: A 10 yr old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of scalp, multiple sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hair, and lymph nodes enlarged in occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnostic evaluation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

KOH mount

The presentation (painful boggy swelling of the scalp = kerion, multiple sinuses with purulent discharge, easily pluckable hairs, and occipital lymphadenopathy) is classic for tinea capitis with intense inflammatory reaction. A KOH mount of plucked hairs and scalp scrapings is the quickest, least invasive and most useful initial test — it will show fungal elements (septate hyphae and arthroconidia) and whether the infection is endothrix (fungus inside the hair shaft) or ectothrix (on the hair surface). KOH is a bedside/clinic test (10–20% KOH), gives rapid confirmation of dermatophyte infection, and guides immediate management; fungal culture (Sabouraud) can be sent in parallel for species identification but takes weeks, so KOH is the most helpful first-line diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 23yearold college student presents with a sore throat, fever, and fatigue. Physical examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy and pharyngitis. A Monospot test is positive.  What is the most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epstein Barr virus (EBV)

The clinical presentation of infectious mononucleosis includes fever, sore throat, fatigue, and cervical lymphadenopathy, which is classic in young adults. The Monospot test, a heterophile antibody test, is highly specific for Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV infects B lymphocytes and is transmitted primarily through saliva (kissing disease). The presence of pharyngitis with generalized fatigue and a positive Monospot test strongly supports EBV as the etiological agent

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with genital ulceration and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. A Gram stain of the ulcer exudate shows gram negative coccobacilli.  List of pathogens given here. Choose the likely pathogens responsible for this condition.
1.Haemophilus ducreyi, 2. Treponema pallidum, 3.Chlamydia trachomatis (L1, L2, L3 serotypes),  4.Herpes simplex virus (HSV)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1, 3 are correct

The patient is a young woman presenting with genital ulceration and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. On Gram stain, gram-negative coccobacilli are seen, which are characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, the causative agent of chancroid. Chlamydia trachomatis (L1, L2, L3 serotypes) causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which also presents with genital ulceration followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (groove sign).

questions.text: A 40-year-old PLHIV man presents with fever, headache, and confusion. CT scan shows multiple ring enhancing lesions in the brain.  All the following organisms could be responsible for his symptoms except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Neisseria meningitidis

In a PLHIV (Person Living with HIV) patient with low CD4 count, multiple ring-enhancing lesions on CT scan of the brain are highly suggestive of opportunistic infections. The most common causes include Toxoplasma gondii, Cryptococcus neoformans, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can all produce space-occupying lesions in the brain. However, Neisseria meningitidis typically causes acute pyogenic meningitis, characterized by diffuse meningeal enhancement, not focal ring-enhancing lesions.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with watery diarrhea after returning from a camping trip. Stool examination shown in the image.  What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Giardia lamblia

A 7-year-old boy presenting with watery diarrhea after a camping trip strongly suggests infection from contaminated water sources such as lakes, streams, or untreated well water. Giardia lamblia is the classic pathogen associated with such exposures. It is a protozoan parasite that attaches to the intestinal mucosa, causing malabsorption, bloating, and foul-smelling watery diarrhea. Microscopy of stool often shows pear-shaped trophozoites or cysts with two nuclei (giving a face-like appearance).

questions.text:
A  55 year old man with a history of cirrhosis presents with fever and abdominal pain. Ascitic fluid analysis shows an elevated white blood cell count and gram negative rods.  List of pathogens given here. What are the likely causative organisms?  
1.Escherichia coli,

2.  Klebsiella pneumoniae ,

3. Proteus mirabilis.

4. Staphylococcus epidermidis,

5. Streptococcus pyogenes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,2 are correct
•    Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in cirrhotic patients is most commonly caused by gram negative rods, particularly E. coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae. \
•    Proteus is less common
•    Staphylococcus epidermidis and Streptococcus pyogenes are not typically implicated in SBP.

questions.text:
A 30 year old woman presents with fever, joint pain, and a maculopapular rash after a recent trip to his village. Laboratory tests show leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. Choose the likely pathogens causing this presentation from the list. 
1. Dengue virus,

2. Zika virus,

3. Chikungunya virus,

4. Ebola virus,

5. Varicella Zoster virus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1, 2, 3, are correct

A 30-year-old woman with fever, joint pain, rash, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia after travel to her village suggests an arboviral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. The three common culprits are Dengue virus, Zika virus, and Chikungunya virus. All of them can cause fever with rash and arthralgia. Dengue often presents with thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, Zika virus with fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and arthralgia, and Chikungunya virus with severe joint pain and rash.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man admitted with the complains of fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and diarrhea. Laboratory results reveal iron-deficiency anemia. A stool examination shows oval eggs with characteristic thin shells and a clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ancylostoma duodenale

The presentation of fatigue, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and iron-deficiency anemia in this patient is highly suggestive of hookworm infection. Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that attaches to the intestinal mucosa and feeds on blood, leading to chronic blood loss and iron-deficiency anemia. The described stool finding — oval eggs with thin shells and a clear space between the shell and the developing embryo — is characteristic of hookworm ova

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and chest pain. He lives in a rural area where agriculture is the main occupation. A chest X-ray shows cavitary lesions in the lungs. Sputum culture reveals septate hyphae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aspergillosis

•    The cavitary lung lesions and the presence of septate hyphae in sputum culture suggest a diagnosis of aspergillosis, particularly chronic pulmonary aspergillosis. 

•    This infection is commonly seen in individuals with underlying lung disease or environmental exposure to mold.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with a red, itchy rash 48 hours after applying a new cosmetic product. The rash is localized to the area where the product was applied. Patch testing reveals a reaction to one of the ingredients in the product. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type IV hypersensitivity
•    This case represents contact dermatitis, a classic example of a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction. 
•    This is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells rather than antibodies. 
•    The reaction occurs 24-48 hours after exposure to the allergen, as seen with the rash developing after using a cosmetic product.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is admitted with a respiratory infection caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. The strain is resistant to multiple antibiotics, including macrolides and tetracyclines. Laboratory testing reveals that the resistance genes are located on a plasmid, which can be transferred to other bacterial cells. What is the most likely method of transfer for this plasmid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conjugation
•    Plasmid-mediated resistance is often spread by conjugation, a process in which genetic material is transferred between bacterial cells through direct contact. 
•    This is the most common mechanism for the transfer of antibiotic resistance plasmids between bacteria. 
•    Transformation involves uptake of free DNA, while transduction involves bacteriophages, and recombination refers to the integration of DNA into the bacterial chromosome.

questions.text: A young adolescent boy complaints of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A Gutzmann`s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What the patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Puberophonia

Puberophonia, also known as mutational falsetto, is a voice disorder seen in adolescent boys who fail to adapt to the lower-pitched voice of adulthood after puberty. Instead, they continue to speak in a persistently high-pitched voice, which often leads to social embarrassment and bullying. The Gutzmann’s pressure test, in which external pressure is applied to the thyroid cartilage while asking the patient to phonate, lowers the pitch temporarily and confirms the diagnosis of puberophonia.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in the hearing pathway from the receptors to the cortex:
1.Auditory Cortex
2. Spiral Ganglion
3.Cochlear Nucleus
4.Lateral Lemniscus
5.Inferior Colliculus
6.Olivary Complex
7.Medial Geniculate Body
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2-3-6-4-5-7-1

The auditory pathway begins at the receptors in the organ of Corti. From here, signals are transmitted to the spiral ganglion (2), which contains the cell bodies of the first-order neurons. These fibers project to the cochlear nucleus (3) in the brainstem. From the cochlear nucleus, fibers ascend to the olivary complex (6), where important processing such as sound localization occurs. The next relay is through the lateral lemniscus (4), which carries auditory fibers upward to the inferior colliculus (5) in the midbrain. From there, impulses are relayed to the medial geniculate body (7) of the thalamus, which serves as the gateway to the auditory cortex (1) in the temporal lobe for conscious perception of sound

questions.text: Utricle develops from which of the following Embryological Structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PARS SUPERIOR

The utricle develops from the pars superior of the otic vesicle (otocyst), which is an embryological structure derived from the surface ectoderm. The otic vesicle divides into two main parts: pars superior and pars inferior. The pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic duct.

questions.text: A 30 yr old female  is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her last pregnancy. Rinne`s Test is negative in both ears and Weber`s Test is Lateralized to the right side. On Otoscopy, tympanic membrane appears normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000Hz. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stapedotomy

The clinical presentation is consistent with otosclerosis, a disease where abnormal bone remodeling occurs at the stapes footplate, leading to conductive hearing loss. The negative Rinne’s test bilaterally and Weber’s lateralization suggest conductive loss. The Carhart’s notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz) on audiometry is a classical finding of otosclerosis. In such cases, the treatment of choice is stapedotomy, a surgical procedure where a small hole is created in the stapes footplate and a prosthesis is inserted to transmit sound vibrations to the inner ear. Stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy as it is less invasive, associated with fewer complications, and provides excellent hearing outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the subjective tests for hearing?
1.Tuning Fork Tests
2.OAE
3.PTA
4.Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1, 3

Subjective tests for hearing are those that require active participation and response from the patient. In this case, Tuning Fork Tests (like Rinne’s and Weber’s) and Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) are subjective. Both rely on the patient’s perception and feedback to sound stimuli. PTA is the gold standard subjective test, as it maps out the hearing threshold across different frequencies. Tuning fork tests are simple bedside subjective tests, useful for differentiating conductive from sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhinolalia Aperta

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a highly vascular, benign but locally aggressive tumor seen in adolescent males. It typically arises from the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into the nasopharynx. The clinical triad includes recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a nasopharyngeal mass. Speech changes can occur due to nasal obstruction, but they manifest as rhinolalia clausa (nasal speech due to blockage), not rhinolalia aperta (which occurs due to velopharyngeal incompetence or palatal defects, leading to excessive nasal resonance). Hence, rhinolalia aperta is not seen in nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 55 years old man, 2 weeks after parotid surgery felt numbness and sensory loss while shaving. Which of the following nerve is most likely to be involved during procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Greater Auricular nerve
Explanation: Greater Auricular nerve supplies only the angle of jaw not the entire skin over the mandible.

A. Eight nerve

questions.text: Woman with known history of diabetes has come to your clinic. Her vision is 6/6. However, on retinal examination, he is classified to have severe NDPR. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Disc Neovascularization
Explanation: Disc neovascularization is a feature of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy not Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy.
NDPR: 4-2-1 rule: A) All 4 quadrants have Microaneurysms
                                B) Venous changes in at least 2 quadrants
                                C) Intra-Retinal Microvascular Anomaly in at least 1 quadrant
If any 1 criteria is present: Severe NDPR
Of any 2 criteria is present: Very severe NDPR

questions.text: A child went to an ophthalmologist and is found to have -2DS and -1DC at 180 degrees. What kind of astigmatism does the child have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

-2DS = Spherical correction for myopia (near-sightedness)

-1DC at 180 degrees = Cylindrical correction for astigmatism, with the axis at 180 degrees

What does this mean?

Compound astigmatism: Both meridians are myopic, but by different amounts.

One meridian has -2.00D

The other has -3.00D (because -2DS + -1DC = -3D in that meridian)

So, both meridians are myopic → this is compound myopic astigmatism

The axis is at 180 degrees, which corresponds to the horizontal meridian. In "with the rule" astigmatism, the vertical meridian is more curved (i.e., has more power), which corresponds to a cylinder axis at 180 degrees.

Summary:

Type: Compound (both meridians myopic)

Orientation: With the rule (cylinder axis at 180 degrees)

choices.text: Increase the length of capsule with the growth
Increase in the size of the capsule covering the diameter

questions.text: While deciding on a lens for cataract surgery in a child what should be kept in mind?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myopic Shift

When deciding on an intraocular lens (IOL) for cataract surgery in a child, it is important to consider the natural growth of the eye. As the child grows, the axial length of the eyeball increases, which leads to a progressive myopic shift. This means that even if the refraction is appropriate immediately after surgery, the child will tend to become more myopic with age. Therefore, surgeons generally under-correct the IOL power (leave the child slightly hypermetropic initially) so that as the eye grows and the myopic shift occurs, the refraction becomes closer to emmetropia. This anticipated myopic shift is the key factor to keep in mind.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complains of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsula opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nd-Yag Laser

Posterior capsule opacification (PCO), also called a “secondary cataract,” is the most common late complication of cataract surgery, occurring due to migration and proliferation of residual lens epithelial cells on the posterior capsule. It leads to decreased visual acuity, glare, and cloudy vision. The standard and effective treatment is Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy, where a focused laser beam creates an opening in the opacified posterior capsule, restoring the visual axis and improving vision. This procedure is quick, non-invasive, and avoids the need for reopening the eye surgically, making Nd-YAG laser the correct choice.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests are not objective tests?
1.Prism bar cover Test
2. Cover-Uncover Test
3. Maddox Rod
4. Hirschberg`s Test
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


3

questions.text: Which of the following is not the cause of Constricted Pupils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Holmes Adie Pupil

Holmes-Adie pupil is typically characterized by a tonically dilated pupil with poor or absent reaction to light but preserved, slow constriction on near response (light-near dissociation). It is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic innervation of the eye, usually idiopathic or due to viral/inflammatory causes. Since this condition produces a dilated pupil (mydriasis) rather than a constricted pupil (miosis), it is not a cause of constricted pupils

questions.text: Recurrent chalazion to be evaluated Histo-pathologically to exclude?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sebaceous Gland Carcinoma

A recurrent or non-resolving chalazion should always be evaluated histopathologically to exclude sebaceous gland carcinoma. This malignancy arises from meibomian glands or glands of Zeis and can closely mimic benign conditions such as chalazion or chronic blepharoconjunctivitis, leading to delayed diagnosis. Sebaceous gland carcinoma is highly malignant, with a tendency for pagetoid spread (into conjunctival epithelium), regional lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis. Because of its aggressive nature and resemblance to recurrent chalazion, histopathological examination is essential to rule it out.

questions.text: All of the following effects are seen when a Pilocarpine is used except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pilocarpine has following effects

(1) They cause contraction of the iris sphincter, leading to miosis
(2) They cause contraction of the circular fibers of the ciliary muscle, resulting in relaxation of the zonular tension, which leads to an increase in accommodation. 
(3) They cause contraction of the longitudinal fibers of the ciliary muscles, which pulls on the scleral spur and opens the trabecular meshwork, promoting aqueous outflow.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is seen for evaluation of recurrent episodes of severe unilateral pain, primarily around his left eye, which are associated with significant conjunctival tearing and rhinorrhea. His differential diagnosis includes Cluster Headache and Paroxysmal Hemicrania. Distinguishing between this two, diagnosis could be done based on a therapeutic response to which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Indomethacin

Cluster headache and paroxysmal hemicrania are both trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) presenting with unilateral orbital/periorbital pain associated with autonomic features such as tearing, conjunctival injection, and rhinorrhea. The key distinguishing feature is therapeutic response: paroxysmal hemicrania responds dramatically and completely to indomethacin, making it diagnostic. Cluster headache, in contrast, does not respond to indomethacin but is treated with oxygen, triptans, and preventive agents like verapamil.

questions.text: Miller Fischer Syndrome is most commonly associated with antibodies to which of the following Gangliosides?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

GQ1b

Miller Fisher Syndrome (MFS) is a rare variant of Guillain–Barré Syndrome (GBS) characterized by the classic triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia. It is most strongly associated with autoantibodies against the GQ1b ganglioside, which is highly expressed in the oculomotor nerves and muscle spindles. The presence of anti-GQ1b antibodies is considered a diagnostic marker, being positive in the majority of MFS cases. These antibodies are pathogenic and contribute to demyelination and nerve dysfunction in the cranial and peripheral nervous system.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Conduction aphasia 

In the given case, the patient has Right Facio-brachial paralysis indicating lesion in the left hemisphere (Dominant/Categorical hemisphere) of the brain which houses speech areas.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Hypokalemia except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Renal Acidosis Type 4 
 

Explanation: Type 4 Renal Tubular Acidosis also called as Hyperkalemic RTA. Here the pathology is Aldosterone Dysfunction either by resistance or by deficiency. As aldosterone is defective it will lead to impaired Na+-K+ Pump activity in distal Tubules and collecting Duct leading to defective absorption of Na+ and impaired secretion of K+ leading to Hyperkalemia. Symptoms of RTA include defective growth, Delayed Milestones, Polyuria and Polydipsia, Palpitations and Cardiac Arrythmia.

choices.text: Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Respiratory Acidosis
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Metabolic Alkalosis+ Respiratory Acidosis
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Respiratory Acidosis
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease came with complaints of vomiting and Diarrhea. His blood gas reports show pH= 7.24, pCO2: 42mm Hg, HCO3-=20mEq/L, Na+= 144mEq/L, Cl-= 100mEq/L. What is your Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 

High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis +Metabolic Alkalosis + Respiratory Acidosis
 

Explanation: 
 

pH= 7.24 i.e Acidosis
Pco2: 42 i.e >40 Respiratory Acidosis
Plasma HCO3-= 20 i.e <24 Metabolic Acidosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Respiratory Acidosis:
For Metabolic Acidosis always calculate Anion Gap:
Anion Gap= Na+ -(Cl- +HCO3-)
                   =144-(100+20)
                   =145-120
                   = 25mEq/L
Delta Ratio = AG-12 / 24-HCO3- = 25-12/ 24-20 = 13/4= >2
(Delta ratio = 1-2 (Normal): Only High Anion Metabolic Acidosis
 Delta ratio= <1 High Anion Metabolic Acidosis + Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis
Delta ratio= >2 High anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Metabolic Alkalosis
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis + Respiratory Acidosis + Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A 35 years old male comes with cough associated with haemoptysis. He also noticed passing blood in the urine. He has a purpuric skin rash over the lower limbs. Ocular examination reveals pan-uveitis and he also has conductive deafness due to serous otitis media. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wegener’s granulomatosis

The patient presents with a triad of upper respiratory tract, lower respiratory tract, and renal involvement, which is classical for Wegener’s granulomatosis (GPA). The features here include: cough with hemoptysis (pulmonary involvement due to alveolar hemorrhage or cavitating nodules), hematuria (renal involvement from pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis), purpuric rash (systemic small vessel vasculitis), ocular involvement (pan-uveitis), and conductive deafness due to serous otitis media (ENT involvement). This systemic constellation of findings points strongly to GPA, which is also characteristically associated with c-ANCA positivity (anti-proteinase 3 antibodies).

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy presents with complaints of Syncope. ECG is suggestive of LV Hypertrophy. A doppler echocardiography revealed abnormal systolic anterior leaflet motion of the mitral valve. Which of the following drugs can be given in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amiodarone

This patient presents with syncope, ECG showing LV hypertrophy, and echocardiography showing systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, which are diagnostic clues for Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM). In HOCM, the hypertrophied interventricular septum causes dynamic LV outflow tract obstruction that worsens with drugs reducing preload or afterload. Antiarrhythmic therapy with Amiodarone is beneficial as it reduces the risk of life-threatening arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially in symptomatic patients with syncope, a known red flag in HOCM.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a diagnosis of Autoimmune hepatitis did not respond well to Glucocorticoids. Which among the following is false regarding her further management options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liver Transplant is contraindicated

In autoimmune hepatitis (AIH), liver transplant is not contraindicated—in fact, it is a definitive treatment option for patients with fulminant hepatic failure, advanced cirrhosis, or those who fail to respond to immunosuppressive therapy. Post-transplant outcomes are generally favorable, and AIH is among the conditions with good long-term survival after liver transplantation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clinical sign that is localized to the left upper limb only. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left Arteriovenous (AV) Fistula

A left arteriovenous (AV) fistula involves an abnormal direct connection between an artery and a vein in the left upper limb. This leads to changes that are localized to that limb, such as increased blood flow, swelling, a palpable thrill (vibration), or even ischemic changes in nearby tissues. Since the clinical signs are restricted to the left upper limb without systemic or widespread effects, a left AV fistula is the most likely cause.

Incorrect Options:

A. Left Lung Abscess
A left lung abscess is a localized infection within the lung tissue, typically causing systemic symptoms like fever, productive cough, chest pain, and malaise. Although the abscess is on the left side, it affects the lungs and does not cause isolated signs restricted to the left upper limb.

B. Bronchiectasis
Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung disease where the airways become permanently widened. It mainly presents with symptoms such as chronic cough, production of large amounts of sputum, and sometimes hemoptysis (coughing up blood). It affects the respiratory system, not the limbs, and therefore would not cause clinical signs localized to the left upper limb.

D. Right Hemiplegia
Right hemiplegia refers to paralysis of the right side of the body, typically due to a brain lesion like a stroke on the left side of the brain. It affects motor control, but on the right side, not the left upper limb. Therefore, it is not consistent with a finding that is limited to the left upper limb.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with a recent diarrheal episode presented to emergency department by parents with complaining of dark urine. He has been Febrile. Serum Creatinine 2 mg/dl, CBC: Hb:7 g/dl, platelets: 38000/microliter, Serum Total Bilirubin :5 mg/dl, indirect bilirubin: 4mg/dl; LDH elevated. What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Supportive Treatment and Observe

This 13-year-old boy presents with dark urine, anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal dysfunction, and a recent diarrheal illness. These findings are classic for Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), typically post–E. coli O157:H7 diarrheal infection. Laboratory findings such as low hemoglobin (microangiopathic hemolytic anemia), thrombocytopenia, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH, and raised creatinine support the diagnosis. The mainstay of treatment for HUS is supportive care (maintaining hydration, controlling blood pressure, dialysis if needed, and transfusion of packed RBCs for severe anemia). Antibiotics and steroids are not useful and may worsen outcomes. Hence, the most appropriate step is supportive treatment and observation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presented with chest pain, radiating to his left arm and jaw. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. An ECG reveals elevated ST-segment depression in leads V1-V4. Troponin levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aspirin, Clopidogrel and Heparin

This 58-year-old man presents with chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw, ECG showing ST-segment depression in leads V1–V4, and elevated troponins, which is diagnostic of Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI). The cornerstone of initial management of NSTEMI includes dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin + Clopidogrel or Ticagrelor) plus anticoagulation (Unfractionated heparin or LMWH) to prevent further thrombus propagation. This regimen stabilizes the patient while risk stratification and planning for early invasive strategies (like PCI) are done

questions.text: A patient serological profile was done which revealed profile was done which revealed: HBsAg positive, anti-HBs negative, anti-HBc IgM negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive. There are no symptoms. Physical examination is normal. What is the next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Check HBV DNA

This patient’s serological profile shows HBsAg positive, anti-HBs negative, anti-HBc IgG positive, and anti-HBc IgM negative, which is consistent with a chronic Hepatitis B infection (not acute, as IgM is absent). The patient is asymptomatic with normal physical exam. The next step is to assess the viral replication activity and infectivity, which is best done by measuring HBV DNA levels. This helps decide whether the patient is in the inactive carrier state or has active chronic hepatitis B requiring treatment.

He had a similar episode 3 days ago which was treated as vertigo with temporary relief of symptoms. He is a known diabetic, hypertensive on regular medication. The relatives deny any history of fall/fever/ear discharge. CT Brain was performed. Following statements his diagnosis are true Except:

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 

Variable Extra-thoracic Obstruction
Explanation: Image shows Airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop which is seen in non-fixed variable extra-thoracic obstruction.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient presented with chest pain and was found to have dilated cardiomyopathy on an echocardiogram. On auscultation, a reversed splitting of second heart sound was heard. Which of the following could most likely be responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

LBBB

Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting of the second heart sound (S2) occurs when the normal sequence of aortic valve closure (A2) before pulmonary valve closure (P2) is reversed, so that P2 occurs before A2. This happens when left ventricular activation and contraction are delayed, which delays closure of the aortic valve. The most common cause is Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). In LBBB, depolarization of the left ventricle is delayed, prolonging left ventricular systole and hence delaying A2. During expiration, this produces a reversed split, where A2 follows P2. Hence, in this patient with dilated cardiomyopathy and chest pain, the reversed splitting is most likely due to LBBB.

questions.text: 30-year-old male presented with weakness and Fatigue. On examination he was pale and his HB-5.8G/dl, TLC-8400/mm3 and Platelets-350000. His CXR showed a mediastinal mass and BM examination revealed a pure red cell aplasia. What is the likely reason for pure red cell aplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Teratoma

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare disorder characterized by severe anemia, reticulocytopenia, and selective absence of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow. While thymomas are classically associated with PRCA, mediastinal germ cell tumors, especially teratomas, have also been linked to this condition due to immune-mediated suppression of erythropoiesis. In this case, the patient has a mediastinal mass and PRCA. Although thymic neoplasia is a common cause, in this specific scenario the correct association given is teratoma, which belongs to the group of mediastinal germ cell tumors.

questions.text: A patient who has presented with skin rashes, hematuria has been diagnosed with Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis. Which of the following drugs would you not use in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anakinra

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener’s granulomatosis) is an ANCA-associated small vessel vasculitis that affects the respiratory tract and kidneys. The mainstay of treatment includes glucocorticoids combined with immunosuppressive agents like cyclophosphamide, rituximab, or methotrexate depending on severity. Anakinra, an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist, is used in conditions like systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis or autoinflammatory syndromes but has no role in GPA management.

questions.text: Man presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reduced Hemoglobin exceeds 2 gm%

Cyanosis refers to a bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes caused by the presence of abnormal or increased quantities of hemoglobin derivatives in the blood. Clinically, cyanosis is usually evident when reduced hemoglobin exceeds 5 g/dL, not 2 g/dL.

questions.text: Which of the following features is least likely to be seen in Cushing`s Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Distal Myopathy

Cushing’s syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. The myopathy associated with Cushing’s syndrome is typically proximal muscle weakness, especially affecting large muscles of the pelvic and shoulder girdles. This is due to protein catabolism in skeletal muscle induced by cortisol

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with CKD presented with bleeding gums and skin rash. He had undergone dialysis 2 weeks ago. Further investigations revealed Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia to be the cause. Which of the following drugs can be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Argatroban

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a prothrombotic condition caused by antibodies against the heparin–PF4 complex. In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), the choice of anticoagulant is important since many agents are renally cleared. Argatroban is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is metabolized in the liver

questions.text: JVP findings: Absent x-descent and Rapid y-descent is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Constrictive Pericarditis

In constrictive pericarditis, the rigid pericardium prevents normal diastolic filling. This produces a prominent y-descent in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) due to rapid early diastolic filling followed by an abrupt halt. Additionally, the x-descent may be absent or blunted because atrial relaxation is impaired. Together, the pattern of absent x-descent and rapid y-descent is highly characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: Dialysis will prevent all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Peripheral Neuropathy
Explanation: Complications like Seizures, Metabolic Acidosis and Uremic Pericarditis can be prevented by Dialysis but not Peripheral neuropathy.
Peripheral neuropathy is caused by middle molecules (50-200 kDa). Conventionally used dialysis membranes have pore size that prevent larger particles such as middle molecules from passing through them. Beta-2-microglobulin, alpha-1-microglobulin and albumin leakage during dialysis session are useful parameters for assessing middle-molecule removal.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with history of Bilateral lower limb weakness which progresses to upper limb in 9 months. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the right upper limb. Babinski`s sign was positive but deep tendon reflexes were negative. No sensory loss or autonomic dysfunction. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ALS 

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that involves both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs without sensory or autonomic involvement. In this patient, the UMN signs are represented by Babinski’s positivity and spasticity, while the LMN signs are shown by muscle wasting and absent deep tendon reflexes. The progression from lower limb to upper limb weakness over several months, with preservation of sensation, strongly supports ALS as the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: ABPI is 1.4 is suggestive of ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Calcified and thickened arteries

The Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is a simple, non-invasive test used to assess peripheral arterial disease (PAD). A normal ABPI ranges from 1.0 to 1.3. When the ABPI is greater than 1.3–1.4, it indicates non-compressible, calcified, and thickened arteries. This is commonly seen in patients with long-standing diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and elderly patients. In such cases, the arteries are stiff and cannot be compressed by the blood pressure cuff, giving a falsely elevated ABPI value

questions.text: Best way to take biopsy from Cancer head of pancreas?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT guided biopsy 

In suspected cancer of the head of the pancreas, the best and most reliable method for tissue diagnosis is CT-guided biopsy. This technique uses real-time imaging guidance to accurately target the pancreatic mass, especially when it is located deep in the retroperitoneum. CT guidance ensures high precision, reduces the chances of sampling error, and avoids injury to surrounding vital structures such as the bile duct, duodenum, and major vessels. Additionally, CT-guided biopsy is minimally invasive and can be performed safely in most patients. This makes it the preferred method for establishing a histological diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common cause of post op thyroid storm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Poor pre-operative preparation euthyroid control of patient

Thyroid storm is a rare but life-threatening complication that can occur after thyroid surgery, characterized by severe hyperthyroidism with fever, tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypertension followed by hypotension, and altered sensorium. The most common cause of post-operative thyroid storm is poor pre-operative preparation, meaning the patient has not been rendered euthyroid before surgery. If surgery is performed while the patient remains hyperthyroid, the stress of anesthesia and surgical manipulation can precipitate a sudden release of thyroid hormones into circulation. Hence, proper pre-operative preparation with antithyroid drugs, β-blockers, and sometimes iodine is mandatory to minimize the risk of thyroid storm.

questions.text: In a case of road traffic accident (RTA), PCO2 falls because of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

None is affected

In a road traffic accident, the most immediate physiological response is acute stress and pain, which commonly leads to hyperventilation. During hyperventilation, the patient breathes rapidly and deeply, resulting in excessive exhalation of carbon dioxide (CO₂). This causes a fall in arterial PCO₂ (hypocapnia). Importantly, this fall in PCO₂ is not due to any damage to the respiratory centre in the brain or the respiratory apparatus (lungs, chest wall, or airways). Instead, it is primarily a functional response driven by anxiety, pain, and sympathetic overactivity

questions.text: A patient presented with peritonitis. Exploratory laparotomy revealed a mass at distal stomach with gastric perforation and 2 metastases in liver. An palliative Gastro-jejunostomy was done with closure of perforation. It is which type of surgical wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Class 1 Clean. They are uninfected, no inflammation is present, and are primarily closed. These wounds do not enter respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts.
Class 2 Clean-contaminated. Class 2 wounds enter the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts. However, these wounds have entered these tracts under controlled conditions.
Class 3 Contaminated. These are fresh, open wounds that can result from insult to sterile techniques or leakage from the gastrointestinal tract into the wound. Additionally, incisions made that result in acute or lack of purulent inflammation are considered class 3 wounds. 
Class 4 - dirty-infected. Traumatic wounds. Wounds demonstrate devitalized tissue, and they most commonly result from microorganisms present in perforated viscera or the operative field.

questions.text: A trauma patient was brought to emergency who has cold clammy skin, increased JVP prominent neck veins and heart sound were not audible. Patient died in the hospital. Autopsy finding is given in the image. Which triad would have been found in this patient on examination, ante-mortem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Beck’s triad 

The autopsy image shows a massive pericardial effusion/hemopericardium, which causes cardiac tamponade. In tamponade, fluid accumulation within the pericardial sac compresses the heart, preventing ventricular filling and reducing cardiac output. Clinically, this presents with Beck’s triad:
Hypotension (due to decreased stroke volume and cardiac output),
Muffled/inaudible heart sounds (due to insulating effect of pericardial fluid),
Raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) with distended neck veins (due to impaired venous return)

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Refeeding syndrome
• Hypophosphatemia is considered a hallmark of refeeding syndrome (RS) and it can cause arrhythmias.
• Other electrolyte irregularities is decreased  magnesium, potassium, and thiamine.
• Hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, and hypocalcemia are not associated with RS.
With rising glucose levels, the body produces a countermeasure of insulin levels, which drives phosphorus and potassium intracellularly, causing a decrease in the amount of available extracellular potassium or hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker male presents with pain along the right arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the right lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. The picture is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Superior pulmonary sulcus tumors, also called Pancoast tumors, arise from the apical pleuropulmonary groove located superior to the first rib. When these tumors involve the surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus, cervical paravertebral sympathetic nervous system, and stellate ganglion, they cause a group of signs and symptoms that are collectively called Pancoast syndrome. This is characterized by ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain, paresthesias, paresis and atrophy of the thenar muscles of the hand, and Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). 
Pancoast syndrome refers to the collective group of symptoms associated with these tumors, which is secondary to the involvement of brachial plexus and associated chest wall, vertebral, or rib pain. Shoulder or arm pain with associated paresthesias along the medial half of the fourth, fifth fingers and medial side of the hand, arm, and forearm due to C8 through T1 radiculopathy are usually primary symptoms associated. Since they are apically located, pulmonary symptoms of shortness of breath do not develop until later, as the tumor begins to involve more of the lung.
Physical examination findings include ipsilateral facial flushing and sweating due to the involvement of the sympathetic trunk and cervical ganglion. Horner syndrome with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis may also develop with the further extent of the tumor.

questions.text: A Chronic alcoholic patient with chronic liver disease presents with hematemesis. He has a report of UGI endoscopy done few weeks back. The image of endoscopy given below. Which of the following treatment is not included in immediate treatment of hematemesis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beta blockers 

In a patient with chronic liver disease presenting with hematemesis, the immediate management focuses on controlling active variceal bleeding and stabilizing the patient. Beta blockers (like propranolol or nadolol) are indeed used in the prevention of variceal bleeding, but they are not part of the immediate treatment in an acute bleeding episode. Their role is in secondary prophylaxis after the acute episode is controlled. Using beta blockers during active hemorrhage can worsen hypotension and compromise patient stability

questions.text: Following an earthquake, the building codes were changed to earthquake-resistant buildings. Which of the following steps of Disaster management does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Disaster Mitigation

Disaster mitigation refers to long-term measures taken to reduce or eliminate the impact of future disasters. It includes proactive steps such as enforcing earthquake-resistant building codes, land-use planning, and strengthening infrastructure to minimize damage in case of natural calamities. In the scenario given, after experiencing an earthquake, the authorities revised building codes to ensure earthquake-resistant structures. This is a clear example of mitigation, as the goal is not to respond to the current disaster but to prevent or minimize the effects of similar events in the future.

questions.text: Placenta is dispose in which color bag following delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Yellow

According to biomedical waste management rules, human anatomical waste (which includes placenta, tissues, organs, and body parts) must be disposed of in the yellow bag. The yellow category is designated for waste that requires incineration or deep burial, since it may be infectious or hazardous. In the case of delivery, the placenta is a biological by-product and is classified under anatomical waste. Therefore, the correct disposal method is in a yellow-colored bag to ensure safe and hygienic handling of biomedical waste and to prevent environmental contamination or disease transmission.

Welfare Benefit

-Medical Benefit

questions.text: Under NTEP, Which of the following is ICT enabled adherence system for TB- HIV Coinfection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DOTS-99

DOTS-99 is a Low cost approach for monitoring and Improving TB medication adherence. It can be utilized either as a supplement to existing DOTS program, or to enable remote observation of doses administered by patients or their family members. 99 DOTS is an IT-enabled pill in hand adherence monitoring system implemented by the National TB Elimination Program (NTEP) for all Drug-Sensitive TB patients on a daily regimen. In this system, the medicine blister packs are wrapped with envelopes which have unique toll-free phone numbers printed on them. Each time a patient dispenses the pills, they break through perforated flaps on the back of the envelope, revealing a hidden Phone number. The patient is expected to give a call to this toll-free number from his registered mobile number to report that they consumed the medication.

questions.text: A public health expert is evaluating various health indicators to assess the health status of a state and district wise the availability and Utilization of health Services. Which indicator is considered the best for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

IMR

Infant Mortality Rate is considered the best single indicator for assessing the health status of a population and evaluating the availability and utilization of health services at the state or district level. IMR measures the number of infant deaths (below 1 year of age) per 1000 live births in a given year. Infants are highly sensitive to changes in environmental conditions, maternal health, nutrition, socioeconomic factors, and access to healthcare. Hence, IMR reflects the overall effectiveness of health services, including antenatal care, safe delivery, neonatal care, immunization, and nutrition programs. Because of its sensitivity to improvements in both healthcare delivery and living conditions, IMR is widely used as a standard measure of community health status.

questions.text: Risk difference in a cohort Study can be calculated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Attributable Risk
Explanation: Attributable risk is the difference between the incidence rates in Exposed and Non-Exposed Group. In a cohort Study, AR is calculated as the difference in Cumulative Incidences (risk difference) or Incidence Densities (rate difference). This reflects the absolute risk of the exposure or the excess risk of the outcome (eg Disease) in the exposed Group compared with the Non-Exposed Group.

questions.text: Which Disease is transmitted by the vector as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Plaque

The image shows a flea, specifically Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea), which is the principal vector of plague, a disease caused by Yersinia pestis. Fleas transmit plague when they bite humans after feeding on infected rodents (rats). The bacillus blocks the flea’s gut, forcing it to regurgitate infected blood into the bite wound, leading to human infection. Clinically, plague can manifest as bubonic plague, septicemic plague, or pneumonic plague. The presence of fleas and their close association with rodents makes them a key epidemiological factor in the spread of plague outbreaks

questions.text: Minimum recommended Ante-Natal visits as per WHO is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

8 visits

According to the updated WHO 2016 recommendations on antenatal care (ANC), a minimum of 8 contacts/visits are advised during pregnancy to improve maternal and perinatal outcomes. This shift from the earlier recommendation of 4 visits is based on evidence that more frequent contacts reduce perinatal mortality, improve quality of care, and strengthen the trust between pregnant women and healthcare providers. The schedule generally includes 1 visit in the first trimester, 2 in the second trimester, and 5 in the third trimester.

questions.text: Risk of cold chain failure is highest at which level ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sub-centre Level

The risk of cold chain failure is highest at the sub-centre level because sub-centres are the most peripheral health facilities and usually lack adequate infrastructure, trained staff, and continuous electricity supply. Vaccines at this level are often stored in carriers or day carriers with ice packs during outreach sessions, making them more vulnerable to temperature fluctuations compared to larger centers with dedicated cold chain equipment (e.g., Ice Lined Refrigerators, Deep Freezers).

questions.text: Due to an effective prevention program, the prevalence of a disease in a community has been reduced by 80%. However, the Physicians continue to use the same screening Test for that Disease. What changes are expected to be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increase in NPV

When the prevalence of a disease decreases, the proportion of true negatives in the screened population increases. This directly improves the Negative Predictive Value (NPV) of a test, which is the probability that a person who tests negative truly does not have the disease. Since prevention programs reduced the prevalence by 80%, there will be far more disease-free individuals, so a negative result is now much more reliable.

questions.text: Identify the instrument as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Kata Thermometer

The instrument shown in the image is a Kata Thermometer, which is specifically designed to measure the cooling power of air (the rate at which heat is lost from a warm body to the surrounding environment). It is commonly used in public health and occupational health to assess comfort levels, ventilation efficiency, and heat stress in working environments. The kata thermometer works by timing how long it takes for the mercury column to fall between two fixed points after the thermometer is warmed. This makes it a valuable tool in environmental and occupational health studies.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct in Hierarchy of Evidence?

1.Randomized Trials

2. Meta-Analysis and Systematic Review

3.Case-Control Study

4.Cohort Study
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

2>1>4>3

The hierarchy of evidence in evidence-based medicine ranks study designs according to the strength and reliability of the evidence they provide. At the top are Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (2), which combine data from multiple high-quality studies, thereby minimizing bias and providing the strongest level of evidence. Next are Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) (1), considered the gold standard for primary research as they minimize confounding and bias. Below RCTs are Cohort Studies (4), which are observational and useful for studying incidence and risk factors but are prone to confounding. At a lower level are Case-Control Studies (3), which are retrospective and more susceptible to bias

questions.text: What is the theme for World Health Day 2024?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

My Health, My right

The theme for World Health Day 2024, celebrated on April 7, is “My Health, My Right.” This theme emphasizes the fundamental right of every person—everywhere—to access quality health services, information, and essential determinants of health such as clean air, safe water, nutrition, adequate housing, and freedom from discrimination. It underscores health as an inherent human right and calls for global action to ensure equitable access for all.
